results.title: A Curious and diverse flora. Pt. 1: Botany Bay
results.creator_credit: Tony Chenn, Nicholas Alexander, Australian Academy of Science and CSIRO
results.brief_description: This film notes the profusion of previously unknown species of plants discovered by Joseph Banks at Botany Bay, such as banksias, the heath-like epacridaceae, the grass-like restionaceae, boronias, xanthorrhoeas, casuarinas and eucalypts. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Beneath the frozen world
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
The Jacques Cousteau team photograph underwater the life and iceforms of Antarctica, during its brief summer. Suitable for Upper Primary level students. No other credits available.

results.title: About sharks
results.brief_description: Notes the identifying characteristics and habits of a variety of sharks, such as the hammerhead and the carpet sharks; and shows their relationship with the smaller fish who clean them of parasites. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: La Jetee
results.brief_description: Set in Paris after the Third World War; an imprisoned man is being used by scientists to investigate time travel. He is haunted by a childhood memory of the pier at Orly Airport, a woman’s face, a man’s death. The fiction is constructed through still photographs. Photographs - images of the past - thus replace moving images with their power to create the illusion of the present. Script by Catherine Varlin, Chris Marker.
results.description:
“A heartbreaking love story that uses still images to entwine the past, present and future in a time-travelling masterpiece.” – filmmaker and The Futures & Other Fictions advisory group member Robert Connolly

results.title: Marriage
results.brief_description: An historical look at the instruction of marriage and the changing role of women within marriage leads to an examination of marriage in contemporary society. Sociologist Jessie Bernard provides an insight into marriage relationships, a Catholic priest lectures to engaged Catholic couples, and a marriage counsellor helps a couple to communicate.

results.brief_description: Public relations film on the recreated goldfield township Sovereign Hill, (Ballarat, Victoria), providing an insight into the lifestyles of the day. No other credits available.

results.title: Who protects the consumer?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman disputes the view that consumers need governmental protection against the business community and that government actions tend to make consumers better off. The best protection, he claims, is the free market where consumers will desert inferior products or sevices. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: What's wrong with our schools?
results.brief_description: Milton Friedman argues that the growing role of government in financing and administering schooling has led to enormous waste of taxpayers money but also to an inferior education system than would have developed had voluntary co-operation played a larger role.
results.description: Milton Friedman argues that the growing role of government in financing and administering schooling has led to enormous waste of taxpayers money but also to an inferior education system than would have developed had voluntary co-operation played a larger role.

results.title: Created equal
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description: Milton Friedman discusses freedom and equality, arguing that a society which maximises the scope for individual choice and action will be more successful at creating equal opportunities for all than a society which seeks to achieve quality through distribution of wealth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts

results.title: From cradle to grave
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman examines government spending, claiming that it leads to fraud and abuse and may not help the very people it sets out to assist. Self-help projects will, he claims, generate work and lead to a more efficient and dynamic system than the Welfare State can provide. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.
